content.raw:
The debian policy (and probably the same in other distributions) is clear about the no-go of embedding libraries inside other libraries or other software. If we made this change in gazebo sources, all our distributions maintainers (including me) will need to patch (and maintain) manually the sources to work with the system version of tinyxml2. What could we do:

 * Debug which versions of tinyxml are affected and report the bug to upstream if it is not fixed.
 * Fix the tinyxml version present in the ubuntu distribution, if possible. Looks a severe bug to me.
 * Reverse the flag and default to use the internal version (this will mainly affect the source builds)-
 * Build our debian packages using the internal version for the affected platforms.
content.html:
The debian policy (and probably the same in other distributions) is clear about the no-go of embedding libraries inside other libraries or other software. If we made this change in gazebo sources, all our distributions maintainers (including me) will need to patch (and maintain) manually the sources to work with the system version of tinyxml2. What could we do:

  • Debug which versions of tinyxml are affected and report the bug to upstream if it is not fixed.
  • Fix the tinyxml version present in the ubuntu distribution, if possible. Looks a severe bug to me.
  • Reverse the flag and default to use the internal version (this will mainly affect the source builds)-
  • Build our debian packages using the internal version for the affected platforms.

content.raw:
How about we add an additional namespace (or change the namspace) to our internal tinyxml2 version? This feels like a good compromise. Our version of tinyxml2 is not exposed through any public API, and it has a different signature from the system tinyxml2.

I checked the versions of tinyxml2 included in Ubuntu up to Xenial. We need version 3, and ubuntu is shipping 2.2.0.
content.html:
How about we add an additional namespace (or change the namspace) to our internal tinyxml2 version? This feels like a good compromise. Our version of tinyxml2 is not exposed through any public API, and it has a different signature from the system tinyxml2.

I checked the versions of tinyxml2 included in Ubuntu up to Xenial. We need version 3, and ubuntu is shipping 2.2.0.

content.raw:
That will improve the situation of mixing gazebo libraries with third party libraries into binaries but the policy is in there for more than this: it tries to minimize the size of binaries loaded in memory (by reusing shared libraries) or minimize the maintenance effort (imaging the need of patching every embedded copy of tinxyml when a security bug appear). My personal opinion is that we should walk in the direction of removing the internal tinyxml copy and this PR would probably make things more difficult.

I know that dealing with bugs in other libraries is a pain, but the bug should be reported with an use case, a patch commited and a backport to 2.x series done if needed (even in released distributions). If we find the patch, I can release a new version of tinyxml in our repository and send the backport to debian/ubuntu. Meantime yes, we can use the internal copy as a workaround but my vote is against of converting it into something permanent.
content.html:
That will improve the situation of mixing gazebo libraries with third party libraries into binaries but the policy is in there for more than this: it tries to minimize the size of binaries loaded in memory (by reusing shared libraries) or minimize the maintenance effort (imaging the need of patching every embedded copy of tinxyml when a security bug appear). My personal opinion is that we should walk in the direction of removing the internal tinyxml copy and this PR would probably make things more difficult.

I know that dealing with bugs in other libraries is a pain, but the bug should be reported with an use case, a patch commited and a backport to 2.x series done if needed (even in released distributions). If we find the patch, I can release a new version of tinyxml in our repository and send the backport to debian/ubuntu. Meantime yes, we can use the internal copy as a workaround but my vote is against of converting it into something permanent.

content.raw:
I agree on all counts, and I wish we had the resources to dedicate to fixing bugs in third party libraries.

Here is a ramble that is mostly me complaining:

* It bugs me that an OS can hamstring a software project. I get that rules and regulations are needed, for a wide variety of reasons. I'm also a firm believer that rules and regulations should never be followed absolutely. There are always very good and valid reasons to bend a rule. In this case, the problem has been fixed in tinyxml2, and I/we do not have the time or resources to trace down the exact problem and attempt a backward compatible fix that may or may not be possible. This type of development does not scale well. Image trying to do this for all our dependencies.

* Size of a binary seems like an individual project decision, not the decision of an OS. We include boost, which dramatically increases library size. We can also do any number of things that makes our binary size larger, or smaller. In this case tinyxml2 is very tiny, and the authors encourage projects to directly include the source. I'm playing devil's advocate here.

* We wrote our own collada parser because the existing parsers were slightly better than horrible. We could do the same here, and completely hiding tinyxml2 withing Gazebo is getting close to that. We have included ODE because of upstream maintenance issues. See my first point about valid reasons to bend rules.

I don't see much of an alternative, unless someone steps up to trace down the bug, generate a backport, and get that submitted to Ubuntu.
content.html:

I'm also a firm believer that rules and regulations should never be followed absolutely. There are always very good and valid reasons to bend a rule. In this case, the problem has been fixed in tinyxml2, and I/we do not have the time or resources to trace down the exact problem and attempt a backward compatible fix that may or may not be possible.   • Size of a binary seems like an individual project decision, not the decision of an OS. We include boost, which dramatically increases library size. We can also do any number of things that makes our binary size larger, or smaller. In this case tinyxml2 is very tiny, and the authors encourage projects to directly include the source. I'm playing devil's advocate here.

  • We wrote our own collada parser because the existing parsers were slightly better than horrible. We could do the same here, and completely hiding tinyxml2 withing Gazebo is getting close to that. We have included ODE because of upstream maintenance issues. See my first point about valid reasons to bend rules.

I don't see much of an alternative, unless someone steps up to trace down the bug, generate a backport, and get that submitted to Ubuntu.

content.raw:
Using library bundles or shared libraries has historically been a decision taken at a distribution level, you can find MacOSX or Windows (using bundles) or most of the GNU/Linux distributions (not using them). The friends of Gentoo wrote [a page about why not using them](https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Why_not_bundle_dependencies). Both models have pros and cons. Taking the decision of using bundles in Gazebo won't save your downstream distribution maintainers (Fedora, Debian, etc) of having to follow the policy of removing them.

So yes, we can change the code in this way, but would be good to keep all the logic in cmake that allows downstream maintainers not to require custom patching. A way of doing it would be to keep all the logic in place but default to use the bundle. We can build our own packages using it but downstream can easily select not to do it in the building cmake arguments.
content.html:
Using library bundles or shared libraries has historically been a decision taken at a distribution level, you can find MacOSX or Windows (using bundles) or most of the GNU/Linux distributions (not using them). The friends of Gentoo wrote a page about why not using them. Both models have pros and cons. Taking the decision of using bundles in Gazebo won't save your downstream distribution maintainers (Fedora, Debian, etc) of having to follow the policy of removing them.

So yes, we can change the code in this way, but would be good to keep all the logic in cmake that allows downstream maintainers not to require custom patching. A way of doing it would be to keep all the logic in place but default to use the bundle. We can build our own packages using it but downstream can easily select not to do it in the building cmake arguments.

content.raw:
Sorry, we probably are calling "debian version" to different things:

 * Packages .deb from osrfoundation repository will be built using the default, so the internal copy after this PR. We can do anything we want with our own packages.
 * Same for the source builds.
 * Packages directly from debian/ubuntu repositories can not use an embedded version of tinyxml (by policy), so they won't be build using our internal copy.

In the case of we have potential users hit by that bug, the workaround would be to use osrfoundation.org .deb repository.

  • Packages directly from debian/ubuntu repositories can not use an embedded version of tinyxml (by policy), so they won't be build using our internal copy.

In the case of we have potential users hit by that bug, the workaround would be to use osrfoundation.org .deb repository.

content.raw:
Thanks for the clarification. 

I just want to make sure the policy you are referring to actually applies here. With this pull request, we are directly compiling into libgazebo_util.so a version of tinyxml2 that has a different namespace from tinyxml2. No headers related to tinyxml2 are installed, and no public facing api uses tinyxml2. Any person can use gazebo with the system install of tinyxml2 without experiencing any problems.

If this policy still holds, I'm inclined to write my own xml parser and ditch tinyxml2. I'd rather re-invent the wheel that have a persistent bug in Gazebo.

No headers related to tinyxml2 are installed, and no public facing api uses tinyxml2. Any person can use gazebo with the system install of tinyxml2 without experiencing any problems.

If this policy still holds, I'm inclined to write my own xml parser and ditch tinyxml2. I'd rather re-invent the wheel that have a persistent bug in Gazebo.

content.raw: It sounds to me like we would be tricking the rules but yes, if you made your own fork of tinyxml with no external exposure, that can pass the debian policy although we could be going against the spirit of these rules.
content.html: It sounds to me like we would be tricking the rules but yes, if you made your own fork of tinyxml with no external exposure, that can pass the debian policy although we could be going against the spirit of these rules.

content.raw:
Right, we would be tricking the rules. I'm mostly playing devils advocate here, I get the rules but the rules seem broken. In this case we have a bug in upstream code. New code of the upstream package works, but the OS is not using for the new code for the foreseeable future. It's also unclear whether a fix can be propagated to earlier versions.

The result is the our program is now broken. According to the rules we'll have to live with broken code, and there is nothing to do except rewrite all the code that we depend upon and call it something different. They is *very* broken. 

Unless there is an alternative, I will will take the rule-bending approach because a non-broken Gazebo is worth far more than strict adherence to the rules.
content.html:
Right, we would be tricking the rules. I'm mostly playing devils advocate here, I get the rules but the rules seem broken. In this case we have a bug in upstream code. New code of the upstream package works, but the OS is not using for the new code for the foreseeable future. It's also unclear whether a fix can be propagated to earlier versions.

The result is the our program is now broken. According to the rules we'll have to live with broken code, and there is nothing to do except rewrite all the code that we depend upon and call it something different. They is very broken.

Unless there is an alternative, I will will take the rule-bending approach because a non-broken Gazebo is worth far more than strict adherence to the rules.

content.raw: I agree with not taking the rules as a solid rock. The alternative is the same for the rest of problems we found in all our dependencies: report upstream and help with the fix and patches. We have started this way, so I'm fine with workarounds until the fix arrives. Once the fix is ready, Debian/Ubuntu maintainers/developers usually backport it to current Ubuntu/Debian versions since it fixes a critical problem.

Once the fix is ready, Debian/Ubuntu maintainers/developers usually backport it to current Ubuntu/Debian versions since it fixes a critical problem.

content.raw:
Here is a script that will reproduce the problem:

```
#!ruby


#!/usr/bin/env ruby

f = File.open("test.log", "w")

f.write("<test><![CDATA[")
for i in 0..100000
  for i in 0..1000
    f.write('00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000')
  end
end
f.write("]]></test>")

f.close()
```

When you playback the log file with tinyxml2 version 2.2, you'll get the following error:


```
#!c++

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:119] Unable to load file[test.log]. Check the Gazebo server log file for more information.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:127] EXCEPTION: Error parsing log file


```

When you playback the logfile with tinyxml2 version 3.0, you'll get:


```
#!c++

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:150] EXCEPTION: Log file is missing the <gazebo_log> element

```

I've included this script the the tinyxml2 issue tracker.
content.html:
Here is a script that will reproduce the problem:

#!/usr/bin/env ruby

f = File.open("test.log", "w")

f.write("<test><![CDATA[")
for i in 0..100000
  for i in 0..1000
    f.write('00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000')
  end
end
f.write("]]></test>")

f.close()

When you playback the log file with tinyxml2 version 2.2, you'll get the following error:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:119] Unable to load file[test.log]. Check the Gazebo server log file for more information.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:127] EXCEPTION: Error parsing log file

When you playback the logfile with tinyxml2 version 3.0, you'll get:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:150] EXCEPTION: Log file is missing the <gazebo_log> element

I've included this script the the tinyxml2 issue tracker.

content.raw:
Instead of manually specifying `USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2`, what if we just search for an external package with version 3 or greater and fall back to the internal copy if that can't be found? Homebrew and Xenial already have the proper versions.

~~~
diff -r 2c371f198820 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Wed Mar 23 10:09:11 2016 -0700
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Thu Mar 24 14:58:06 2016 -0700
@@ -209,8 +209,14 @@
 
   # Use system installation on UNIX and Apple, and internal copy on Windows
   if (UNIX OR APPLE)
-    message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
-    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2_VERSION_3 tinyxml2>=3)
+    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 True)
+    if (TINYXML2_VERSION_3_FOUND)
+      message (STATUS "Using system tinyxml2.")
+    else()
+      message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
+      set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    endif()
   elseif(WIN32)
     message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
     set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
~~~
content.html:
Instead of manually specifying USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2, what if we just search for an external package with version 3 or greater and fall back to the internal copy if that can't be found? Homebrew and Xenial already have the proper versions.

diff -r 2c371f198820 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Wed Mar 23 10:09:11 2016 -0700
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Thu Mar 24 14:58:06 2016 -0700
@@ -209,8 +209,14 @@

   # Use system installation on UNIX and Apple, and internal copy on Windows
   if (UNIX OR APPLE)
-    message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
-    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2_VERSION_3 tinyxml2>=3)
+    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 True)
+    if (TINYXML2_VERSION_3_FOUND)
+      message (STATUS "Using system tinyxml2.")
+    else()
+      message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
+      set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    endif()
   elseif(WIN32)
     message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
     set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
